Hi!

Regarding (1):

You can pause Heritrix mid-crawl to cease network and disk activity 
(without quitting the program/process), then resume later. You can also 
'checkpoint' a crawl to save its entire state to disk, allowing you to 
quit the program completely. Later, you can launch Heritrix again and 
'resume from checkpoint' to continue from the saved point.

Regarding (2):

Heritrix expects to be configured and monitored via its web interface, 
after being launched from the command-line. But, most tasks can be 
automated through command-line operations if necessary ï¿½ in the latest 
H3 versions, typically by synthesizing web requests against the web 
interface.

To launch, configure, and monitor Heritrix crawls it helps to have (or 
acquire) some familiarity with how Java applications and code are 
structured, as tuning its behavior for your system/workload can require 
tinkering with Java options, and configuring optional features usually 
means choosing between alternate included code-modules. (You will see 
Java class names mixed in the interface and logs quite often.)

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA
